@housejester Thanks for reporting this. Working on a fix.

Good detective work!

Thread queues cannot usually be counted on to have any sort of predictable priority to them. As such, even with 2 threads it should be very easy to come across this case.

Additionally, I'm really confused how `new PriorityBlockingQueue<Runnable>()` in `PrioritizedExecutorService` works (if it does indeed work).

@drcrallen Queries can optionally set a priority to them in the context, and the PriorityBlockingQueue is used to hold pending queries that should eventually be runbased on the order of their priorities. 

@housejester It seems like you are just using the default examples, which should definitely work better out of the box. I've created a PR to set better values as defaults for examples, although I think it is worthwhile for us to test the examples more before declaring any kind of stable. Thanks for the catch!

@fjy : thnx, I think the answer to my question previously was that it's effectively a `PriorityBlockingQueue<PrioritizedListenableFutureTask>`. But if it happens to be sharing the same executor service with things that are `Runnable` and not `PrioritizedListenableFutureTask` then it is not clear to me what the execution order would be.

@xvrl : I looked into it a bit, and there's not an obvious way to slow down zookeeper in a reliable fashion that I could think of quickly.
IIRC there's supposed to be code to sanitize distributed filesystem paths. (`:` bad) https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-3257

The comment on the UT says that it is undefined what happens when the empty string is returned.  The docs on DimExtractionFn say that you should not return the empty string and should return null instead.

That seems consistent to me?  The purpose of the test is actually to make it clear when we make a change that will affect what happens when the empty string is returned.  At a minimum we should do something that doesn't bring the server down, for example...

I think this change should be safe.  Though I do agree with @drcrallen that we are probably lacking in test coverage.  It's probably too much to ask to get a unit test in here, but if we could take this chance to think about how this could be unit tested and maybe put those thoughts into an Issue, that might be useful?

Also, if memory serves, the HadoopIndexerJob does the rollup portion of its processing totally in the reducer, meaning if that the data isn't rolled up ahead of time, then we are pushing a lot more data across the wire than needed.  It's use case dependent, but I would think that getting a combiner involved such that we can do a partial rollup might actually result in better overall performance of the hadoop jobs.  This also isn't a reason to block this PR, just a thought that came to mind when read the code.

Agree, doing it as part of the map / combine phase could certainly help reduce time spent pushing data. That's a bigger change though and something I wouldn't want to include at the last minute. The purpose of this fix is purely to help memory pressure be a function of segment size rather than data size.
FYI: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1119 That PR allows native java URL.openStream() to work on HDFS and S3/S3N

I think the intent of this is to support running Druid from Marathon. I think that would be best done with a wrapper script that translates the Marathon environment variables to jvm args.

FWIW - internal projects on which I'm involved we've began using configuration handlers that use config files but individual configs are overridden by environment variables (ie: com.typesafe.config). Following this pattern makes moving towards Docker easier and avoids yet another script / file that can be affected by divergence.

I'm not really a fan of hard-coding environment variables in Druid configuration classes, especially vague ones like PORT. I'd prefer asking people to write wrapper scripts that take $PORT and turn it into -Dio.druid.port="$PORT". We could provide scripts like this for our favorite execution environments if we want.

This is for a couple of reasons.

First, I think we have enough ways of specifying configs: the properties file for pre-distributed stuff and jvm system properties for injected-at-startup stuff. Other than some whackiness with the Hadoop extensions, that's also all tucked away in the PropertiesModule, meaning there's just one place in the code that static properties can originate from. I think that's good.

Second, the purpose of these sorts of environment variables is to make it easier to run Druid in some execution environment. Those environments aren't standardized, so I don't think the benefit of simplifying just one of them is worth the potential annoyance of having things like this hard-coded.

If we do go with this patch, it definitely needs to include documentation, and should probably be part of new docs section describing what environment variables Druid respects.

I have two major TODOs that need tackling before this can be merged, I'm going to close down this PR until I address the TODOs.

This means that the current topN algorithm is ok at determining "who is in the topN", but not so great at getting exact values.

I propose the following solutions:
1. Change the name of the current query to "aliasingTopN" or some other name to indicate it is not a true TopN.
2. Implement a smarter topN algorithm.

For "smarter topN" I have three initial thoughts.

### 2-Query topN

The first is to simply do a topN with ONLY the aggregate of interest to find the expected topN of the dimension of interest, then do a second topN with all aggregates using only the topN values we think will end up in the topN. So 1 query would be expected to be quick because there would be almost no aggregates, and the second would be quick as well, because the results that need aggregating are greatly decreased as well due to the filter on the first results

### Probably topN

The second thought is to have the query service be smarter about the topN results it is merging. Specifically, it could have knowledge of the individual topN results and the results relative rankings. For example: If a dimension value has the following ranks in the resultant segments: `[1, 2, 1, 4, 1]`, it is probably a perfect representation of the underlying data. But if another value has the following ranks in the returned segments : `[N/A, 2, 800, N/A, 5, 300]` Then it is very possible the results do not contain all the data for the value. This approach would essentially look at the variance in segment rank for each value and figure out how confident it is that the value has all its underlying data.

### groupBy topN

The broker issues a groupBy query to the historicals and does the topN on the results that come back. I'm not a huge fan of this approach because it requires a lot of communication overhead.

These are just some initial brainstorms and I'm very open to any other suggestions.
After chatting with @xvrl  for a bit, I think the solution for now is to update the docs to clarify when NOT to use a topN and either close this or leave it as a feature request.

log4j2 original PR: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1011
Just as an FYI

By and large Druid uses the [MMX logger](https://github.com/metamx/java-util/blob/master/src/main/java/com/metamx/common/logger/Logger.java).

Is jul for capturing non-druid logging? or is it included for some other reason?

Thank you Lew, Druid uses [Rhino](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/Rhino) as its underlying JavaScript engine, so you might want to file a bug there.

JavaScript aggregators mainly should be thought of as a prototyping / ad-hoc tool, but if you are looking to use this in production I would recommend implementing this type of aggregator natively in Java.

That being said, `Date.parse` was completely implementation specific (no guarantees beyond being able to parse `Date.toString` format) until the ES5 spec, which defines a subset of ISO-8601. Rhino claims to support most of ES5, but there may still be some quirks like that.

Currently Druid uses Rhino 1.7RC4, but it looks like [RC5 was just released a few weeks ago](https://github.com/mozilla/rhino/releases/tag/Rhino1_7R5_RELEASE), so we can try updating Druid to that to see if that addresses this particular problem, among others.

@drcrallen Yes, the jul dependency would be for non-druid classes that druid winds up using. To be clear, the jul change is not included in this PR, I just thought it worth mentioning/discussing whether it should be (jcl too for that matter). 

If I'm managing a Druid service in production, and trying to tune the logging to only go to file or otherwise tune the levels (or have a consistent log format), Druid out of the box doesn't allow me to do that only using a log4j2.xml file. This is because some components (like jersey) are using jul, and that logger is not configured so it will just go to console. I'd either need to add a separate jul logging config, or drop in the log4j jul jar and set the command line arg myself. Same for jcl (which seems like is used by dbcp which is used in the db metadata connector stuff.

I just tested with Rhino 1.7RC5, and UTC offset parsing still appears to be broken, therefore I suggest you file a bug with the Rhino project, and I will close this issue for now.

In the future we are planning to have Druid use the much-improved Nashorn JavaScript engine that comes with Java 8, and we have some initial code for that, but it has not been a priority to polish this and include it.

In the meantime, if implementing this aggregation natively is not an option, it should be possible to use Joda-Time classes directly in your JavaScript code instead of relying on the limited JavaScript implementation.

You can squash in your current branch, PR commit history should not matter to anyone until it has been merged into our working branches. We rewrite PR commit history all the time before merging. I wrote up instructions on squashing here if that's helpful: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

@drcrallen For samples it's not unit testing but having automated tests for them is as critical or more critcal than the rest of the system as it impacts adoption. I would check in with Gautam on the best way to approach it.

@drcrallen Automated testing for examples is a larger discussion and I don't think we need to have it here. But I agree it is very important and should be proposed to the community.

@sharrissf Please use github tags for individuals so the rest of the community knows who you are referring to.

I didn't closely look at every test, but I believe the following is true:
1) No existing tests were changed and the removals are only for dead code
2) The tests run in a reasonable time
3) The tests are increasing code coverage for Druid, which is very important
4) The code follows the style guide

I am in favor of this PR if the above is true.
There seem to be a few non unit test changes in this PR, can those be separated more clearly somehow?

I think we should take the opportunity to talk about whether we want to make changes to the rules table and replace entries rather than append them. Now that we have an audit table, it may not make sense to append rules to the rule table.
I'm in agreement with @fjy , but I would really like to see the non-unit tests items in at least a separate commit so its more obvious they are changing.
The non-unit test changes are all fixing bugs that exist in the current code found by the unit tests.  If we remove them, the tests won't pass and then travis will be upset and then what do we do?
@fjy  all of what you said is true.
@cheddar : Put them in the same PR as per https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1044
Can I propose a simpler fix of just throwing a meaningful exception when agg/postagg match?

@fjy : That is possible, but be aware that the current proposed fix overwrites the prior values with new ones. This means that if someone has complex aggregations and some other post-aggregations, the post aggs will overwrite the aggregators in the results set, this saves on ser/de when sending back to the client.

I'm on board with all those fixes + changes, I updated the PR title to include the fact that we fixed things.
